narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot of math skills, and a lot of good new ways to think about chemistry. Because of this course feel a lot more comfortable reading papers that discuss these topics
Going into this course, I had little background in statistical mechanics, so mostly everything was new for me
I built upon the my existing foundational knowledge of statmech. I found it also complimented my quantum mechanics class a lot.
We learned the fundamentals of statistical mechanics, including how to derive and solve problems related to statistical mechanics. We also learned about systems related to statistical mechanics
How to code in python and apply projects to python
the basic definitions of statistical mechanics
how statistics plays into quantum mechanics
I developed a deep understanding of the advanced tools of statistical mechanics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Lot of independent work which is good
Could have more structure or clear deadlines
I liked how we were able to choose our own midterm project, so we could look at the part of the course that interested us the most

A strength of the course is how engaging the material it is. A weakness of the course is the specific way it is difficult and a lack of learning objectives. The homework is frustrating as I do not feel like I would be able to do it without going to the professor for help or seeing how he does it in class. While I ultimately am able to complete the homework, I do not feel like I am reinforcing the skills we learn in class. I think the problems outside of class would be more rewarding if they more directly aligned with their lectures and if the lectures had explicit learning goals. We learn a lot each class, but I am not sure where I should be prioritizing my focus. Saying at the beginning of class "Today, we will learn how to correct for the Gibbs paradox and how to use the Sterling approximation" would be beneficial. Otherwise, I am unsure what I should take away from the class. I often wonder if I should be focused on the math or the concept. In the most recent classes, I really appreciate how the professor asked if we had any questions on the previous lecture before and that he would review a simple scenario/formula when introducing a complex mathematical tool (e.g. taylor series, geometric series, sterling aprox) before using it for a derivation.
Any question--from one on the subject-specific concepts to math--were all viable. It was a really welcoming environment.

The strengths of the course are that the material is reviewed several times, and the classes are led by student questions. The weaknesses of the course are that it lacks a coherent structure, which can make the material very hard to follow. The in-class derivations are difficult to follow, and a lot of steps are skipped over without much explanation. The homeworks are also very difficult, take a long time, and no feedback is given, so it is hard to know if you are keeping up with the course.
More structured lectures
no feedback was given on work
it was very informational but the content and lectures were a little too all over the place for my full understanding of many concepts

The strength is the absolute brilliance of Prof. Batista, who gave all lectures without ever looking at his notes and deriving all things on a chalkboard. This is, without exaggeration, an exceptional professor from whom you can learn a lot and he always takes great care of ensuring everyone who wants to understand the concepts does so (as such, he responds to every question asked).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
No, unless it was for audit. It is immensely interesting, but very difficult. I wish I could enjoy the class without having to worry about a grade.
Yes, because it goes over extremely fundamental concepts that any chemist would find useful.
I think the material covered in this course is good for anyone who wants to learn statistical mechanics. However, the lack of structure makes it hard for students to learn the material.
Yes but only if you have to take it
no

Probably not at least to other environmental engineers. It wasn't super relevant to what I was doing. It maybe provided me some background and was nice to cover, but it was a lot of work and sometimes very hard to follow
Yes, but only if you've already have some experience with statistical mechanics on some intro level.
